summary:
The story is about an ordinary family, the Dursleys, who are very concerned with normalcy and dislike anything strange or mysterious{tuple_delimiter} The Dursleys are described as proud of their normality, with Mr. Dursley being a director of a drilling firm and Mrs. Dursley being obsessed with spying on her neighbors.
The Dursleys have a secret fear: their sister, Mrs. Potter, and her husband{tuple_delimiter} They haven't met in years because they find the Potters "unDursleyish" and worry about what people would say if they were to visit. 
Mr. Dursley notices something peculiar on his way to work - a cat reading a map{tuple_delimiter} He dismisses it as a trick of the light, but the cat continues to act strangely, looking at signs and seemingly understanding them.


{completion_delimiter}

Mr. Dursley is deeply uncomfortable with anything unusual {tuple_delimiter} He dislikes people who dress in funny clothes and finds the cloaked individuals unsettling.
Mr. Dursley dismisses the strange occurrences as a silly stunt or a collection effort {tuple_delimiter}  He initially attributes the cloaked figures to a fundraising activity, despite their odd behavior. 
The mention of "the Potters" and "Harry" causes Mr. Dursley intense fear {tuple_delimiter} He tries to rationalize it away but remains deeply disturbed by the encounter.
Mr. Dursley is shaken by his interaction with the cloaked individuals and struggles to concentrate on his work {tuple_delimiter}  He becomes increasingly anxious throughout the day, culminating in a bizarre encounter with a man wearing a violet cloak who calls him a "Muggle."


{completion_delimiter}

Mr. Dursley is concerned about unusual events happening in his town {tuple_delimiter}  He mentions owls flying during the day, shooting stars falling, and strange-looking people.
Mr. Dursley suspects that these events might be connected to his sister-in-law, Petunia's, family, the Potters {tuple_delimiter} He is worried about the potential consequences of being related to them, as he believes they are "a pair of..." and doesn't want people to find out.
Mr. Dursley tries to downplay his concerns to his wife, Mrs. Dursley {tuple_delimiter} He avoids mentioning the name "Potter" directly but hints at it by asking about their son's age and name.


{completion_delimiter}

Mr. Dursley believed the Potters wouldn't come near him and his wife {tuple_delimiter} He thought they knew what he and Petunia thought about them and their kind, and that they couldn't get mixed up in anything going on.
Albus Dumbledore arrived at Privet Drive unnoticed {tuple_delimiter} He was tall, thin, and old with long robes, a purple cloak, and high-heeled boots. His blue eyes were bright behind half-moon spectacles and his nose was very long and crooked. 
Dumbledore used a Put-Outer to extinguish the streetlights {tuple_delimiter} This allowed him to move unseen down the street towards number four, where he sat next to a cat.

{completion_delimiter}

Professor McGonagall is concerned about rumors spreading among Muggles {tuple_delimiter} "People are being downright careless, out on the streets in broad daylight, not even dressed in Muggle clothes, swapping rumors."  She fears that if Muggles discover the existence of magic, it could have disastrous consequences. 
Professor McGonagall is anxious about the disappearance of Voldemort and wants to know what Dumbledore knows {tuple_delimiter} "As I say, even if You-Know-Who has gone —" She presses him for information about why Voldemort disappeared and what happened in Godric's Hollow.
The rumors circulating suggest that Voldemort went to Godric's Hollow to kill the Potters, Lily and James, and their son Harry {tuple_delimiter} "What they’re saying, is that last night Voldemort turned up in Godric’s Hollow. He went to find the Potters. The rumor is that Lily and James Potter are — are — that they’re — dead.”
According to the rumors, Voldemort was unable to kill Harry Potter {tuple_delimiter} "They’re saying he tried to kill the Potters’ son, Harry. But — he couldn’t. He couldn’t kill that little boy."  This supposed failure is believed to have broken Voldemort's power and led to his disappearance. 
Professor McGonagall is shocked and struggling to comprehend the news of the Potter's deaths {tuple_delimiter} "Lily and James . . . I can’t believe it . . . I didn’t want to believe it . . . Oh, Albus . . .” She expresses disbelief and grief over the loss of her friends.


{completion_delimiter}

Dumbledore believes that Harry Potter should be raised by his aunt and uncle {tuple_delimiter} He thinks it's the best place for him because they will be able to explain everything to him when he's older. Dumbledore also wrote them a letter explaining the situation.
Professor McGonagall is concerned about Harry being raised by the Dursleys {tuple_delimiter} She believes that they are not like magical people and won't understand Harry. She thinks Harry will be famous and that the Dursleys won't be able to handle it. 
Hagrid brings Harry Potter to the Dursleys' house {tuple_delimiter} He borrowed a motorcycle from Sirius Black to transport Harry. Hagrid got Harry out of his home before Muggles arrived and Harry fell asleep during their flight over Bristol.


{completion_delimiter}

Main Argument One: The Dursleys are uncaring towards Harry{tuple_delimiter}The text states that the photographs on the mantelpiece showed Dudley, but there was no sign at all that another boy lived in the house, too. This implies that Harry is not treated as a part of the family and his presence is largely ignored.
Main Argument Two: Hagrid, McGonagall, and Dumbledore are deeply affected by Lily and James' death{tuple_delimiter}The text describes Hagrid sobbing uncontrollably, Professor McGonagall blinking furiously, and Dumbledore's twinkling eyes seeming to have gone out. This demonstrates their profound sadness and grief over the loss of Harry's parents.
Main Argument Three: Despite being placed with the Dursleys, Harry is destined for greatness{tuple_delimiter}The text mentions that people are holding up glasses and saying "To Harry Potter — the boy who lived!" in hushed voices. This foreshadows Harry's future importance and his role as a hero in the wizarding world. 

{completion_delimiter}

Harry is mistreated by his aunt, uncle, and cousin {tuple_delimiter}  He sleeps in a cupboard under the stairs full of spiders, wears Dudley's hand-me-downs, and is constantly berated for his appearance and treated poorly.
Dudley is spoiled and entitled {tuple_delimiter} He receives numerous expensive gifts on his birthday, throws tantrums when he doesn't get what he wants, and enjoys punching Harry as a form of entertainment. 
Harry is mistreated because he is an orphan {tuple_delimiter}  His aunt Petunia tells him that she dislikes him because he reminds her of his parents who died in a car crash.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry is mistreated by the Dursleys {tuple_delimiter}  Every year on Dudley's birthday, Harry was left with Mrs. Figg, a woman he disliked, while his cousin and his parents went out for the day. The Dursleys often spoke about Harry as if he were something unpleasant, like a slug.
The Dursleys are overprotective of Dudley {tuple_delimiter}  When Mrs. Figg broke her leg, they panicked about who would look after Dudley on his birthday. They considered leaving Harry at the zoo in the car and even threatened to put him in the cupboard if he caused any trouble. 
Harry is blamed for strange occurrences {tuple_delimiter} When Aunt Petunia cut Harry's hair short, it grew back to its original length overnight.  The Dursleys punished Harry for this despite his explanation that he couldn't control what happened.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry has a difficult relationship with his aunt, uncle, and cousin {tuple_delimiter} He is treated poorly by them, forced to live in a cupboard, and denied food as punishment.  The snake escapes its enclosure and causes chaos at the zoo {tuple_delimiter} The snake's escape is attributed to Harry talking to it, leading to further punishment from his aunt and uncle. Harry has mysterious memories of a car crash involving green light and pain on his forehead {tuple_delimiter} He doesn't remember his parents or anything about them, as they are never mentioned by his relatives and there are no pictures of them in the house. 

{completion_delimiter}

Harry is treated poorly by his aunt, uncle, and cousin {tuple_delimiter} He is often punished unfairly, ignored, and made to feel unwelcome in his own home. Harry feels isolated and lonely at school {tuple_delimiter}  He has no friends because Dudley's gang bullies him and everyone else is afraid of them. Harry looks forward to going to secondary school {tuple_delimiter} He hopes that it will be a fresh start where he can escape from the constant torment of his cousin and his gang. 

{completion_delimiter}

Harry receives a mysterious letter addressed to him {tuple_delimiter} The letter is written on heavy parchment, has an emerald-green address, and a purple wax seal with a coat of arms. It arrives alongside a bill and a postcard from Uncle Vernon's sister.
Uncle Vernon reacts badly to the letter {tuple_delimiter} He becomes increasingly pale as he reads it, eventually turning the color of porridge. He hides the letter from Harry and Dudley, who both want to read it. 
Aunt Petunia is also frightened by the letter {tuple_delimiter} She questions how the sender could know where Harry sleeps and worries that they are being watched or followed.


{completion_delimiter}

The Dursleys are trying to hide Harry's magical identity {tuple_delimiter} They burn his first letter and tell him it was a mistake, then move him to Dudley's broken room to avoid further letters.
Harry suspects the sender of the letters knows about his move {tuple_delimiter} He believes they will try again and plans to make sure this time they succeed. 
The Dursleys are overreacting to Harry receiving letters {tuple_delimiter} They resort to violence and threats, showing their fear and desperation to keep Harry's magical life a secret.

{completion_delimiter}

Uncle Vernon is determined to isolate Harry and keep him away from any letters {tuple_delimiter} He drives them to remote locations like forests, fields, bridges, and parking garages in an attempt to evade anyone who might be looking for Harry.  He also takes them to a desolate shack on a rock during a storm, making it nearly impossible for anyone to reach them.
Uncle Vernon is acting strangely and seems to have a hidden agenda {tuple_delimiter} He is secretive about his actions, doesn't respond to Aunt Petunia's questions, and appears pleased with their isolation. His gleeful attitude towards the storm and his desire to be unreachable suggest he has something to hide. 
Harry suspects that Uncle Vernon is trying to prevent him from receiving mail {tuple_delimiter}  He realizes that the letters are important to Harry and that Uncle Vernon wants to keep them away from him. This suspicion is heightened by Uncle Vernon's insistence on staying in remote locations and his seemingly pleased reaction to their isolation during a storm. 

{completion_delimiter}

The storm intensifies throughout the night {tuple_delimiter} The storm rages more and more ferociously as the night went on. Harry couldn’t sleep. He shivered and turned over, trying to get comfortable, his stomach rumbling with hunger. Dudley’s snores were drowned by the low rolls of thunder that started near midnight.
Harry is apprehensive about his birthday {tuple_delimiter}  He lay and watched his birthday tick nearer, wondering if the Dursleys would remember at all, wondering where the letter writer was now. 
A mysterious figure arrives at the hut {tuple_delimiter} BOOM. The whole shack shivered and Harry sat bolt upright, staring at the door. Someone was outside, knocking to come in.


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid introduces himself as a giant and Keeper of Keys at Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He arrives at Harry's house with a birthday cake and offers tea and sausages.
Harry is unaware of Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid expresses shock that Harry doesn't know about Hogwarts, his parents, or the magical world. 
Hagrid believes Harry should know about his famous parents {tuple_delimiter} He states that Harry's mother and father are famous and that Harry himself is famous.
Uncle Vernon forbids Hagrid from telling Harry anything {tuple_delimiter}  He commands Hagrid to stop talking to Harry about magic and his parents. 


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid reveals to Harry that he is a wizard {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid tells Harry that Dumbledore left him a letter, which the Dursleys kept from him. He states that Harry's parents were wizards and that it's about time Harry read his letter.
Harry receives an acceptance letter to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry {tuple_delimiter} The letter informs Harry of his acceptance, lists necessary books and equipment, and requests a reply by owl no later than July 31st.
The Dursleys are aware of Harry's magical heritage {tuple_delimiter} Aunt Petunia reveals that she knew about Lily Potter being a witch and that she saw her perform magic during vacations. She also mentions that they tried to suppress Harry's magical side.


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid reveals the truth about Harry's parents' death {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid tells Harry that his parents were killed by Voldemort, not in a car crash as he was previously told. He emphasizes the severity of Voldemort's actions and the fear he instilled in the wizarding world. 
Voldemort targeted Harry's parents because they were close to Dumbledore {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid explains that Voldemort likely wanted to eliminate Harry's parents because they were too loyal to Dumbledore and opposed his dark ambitions.  
Hagrid describes Voldemort as a powerful and evil wizard {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid uses phrases like "as bad as you could go," "worse than worse," and "Dark days" to describe the terror Voldemort brought upon the wizarding world. 


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid believes Harry is famous because he survived You-Know-Who's attack {tuple_delimiter}  You-Know-Who killed Harry's parents and many other powerful witches and wizards, but he couldn't kill Harry. Hagrid says that a powerful curse touched Harry, which protected him from You-Know-Who.
Harry is special because he survived You-Know-Who's attack {tuple_delimiter}  Hagrid states that no one else survived after You-Know-Who decided to kill them. 
You-Know-Who disappeared after trying to kill Harry {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid says that You-Know-Who vanished the same night he tried to kill Harry, which makes Harry even more famous.

{completion_delimiter}

Harry believes that when he is upset or angry strange things happen to him {tuple_delimiter} He has found himself out of reach from Dudley's gang when he was upset, his haircut grew back when he dreaded going to school and the last time Dudley hit him Harry set a boa constrictor on him without realizing it.
Hagrid believes that Harry is destined for Hogwarts{tuple_delimiter} Hagrid says "Harry Potter, not a wizard — you wait, you’ll be right famous at Hogwarts." 
Uncle Vernon refuses to let Harry go to Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He says "Haven’t I told you he’s not going? He’s going to Stonewall High and he’ll be grateful for it. I’ve read those letters and he needs all sorts of rubbish — spell books and wands and —”
Hagrid defends Harry's right to go to Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid says "If he wants ter go, a great Muggle like you won’t stop him. Stop Lily an’ James Potter’s son goin’ ter Hogwarts! Yer mad. His name’s been down ever since he was born. He’s off ter the finest school of witchcraft and wizardry in the world."
Uncle Vernon insults Dumbledore {tuple_delimiter} Uncle Vernon yells "I AM NOT PAYING FOR SOME CRACKPOT OLD FOOL TO TEACH HIM MAGIC TRICKS!"


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid is taking Harry to London for school {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid says Gringotts, the wizard bank, has dragons guarding it and is hundreds of miles under London.  He also mentions that the Ministry of Magic keeps magic hidden from Muggles because they would want magic solutions to their problems. 
The Ministry of Magic is run by Cornelius Fudge {tuple_delimiter} Dumbledore was wanted for Minister but he wouldn't leave Hogwarts, so Fudge got the job instead. Hagrid says Fudge constantly asks Dumbledore for advice.
Hagrid is unfamiliar with Muggle customs and money {tuple_delimiter} He struggles with the ticket barrier on the Underground and complains about the size of the seats and the speed of the trains. 


{completion_delimiter}

The Leaky Cauldron is a famous wizarding pub {tuple_delimiter} It was described as a tiny, grubby-looking pub that most people seemed to overlook. The patrons were mostly old women drinking sherry and a few other individuals like the bartender and a man in a top hat. 
Harry Potter is recognized and welcomed by everyone at the Leaky Cauldron{tuple_delimiter} Upon entering, everyone stopped talking and stared at Harry. The bartender was overjoyed to see him and greeted him warmly.  Many patrons came forward to shake his hand and express their admiration for him.
Hagrid introduces Harry to Professor Quirrell, one of his teachers at Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} Professor Quirrell is nervous and stammering when he meets Harry. He teaches Defense Against the Dark Arts and seems apprehensive about the subject. 


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid introduces Harry to Diagon Alley {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid tells Harry he is famous and that even Professor Quirrell was nervous to meet him. He also mentions that Professor Quirrell had some scary experiences, including meeting vampires and a hag in the Black Forest.

Diagon Alley is a magical place with unique shops {tuple_delimiter}  Harry sees shops selling cauldrons, owls, robes, telescopes, strange silver instruments, bat spleens, eels' eyes, spell books, quills, parchment, potion bottles, globes of the moon and more. 

Gringotts bank is a heavily guarded institution {tuple_delimiter} The entrance to Gringotts is described as a snowy white building with burnished bronze doors guarded by goblins. There is a warning inscription above the silver doors that warns against greed and theft.


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid retrieves a golden key from his pocket {tuple_delimiter} The goblin verifies that the key is correct.
Hagrid presents a letter from Professor Dumbledore about vault seven hundred and thirteen {tuple_delimiter} The goblin reads the letter and agrees to take Hagrid and Harry to both vaults. 
They travel through a narrow passageway on a cart {tuple_delimiter}  The passageway is lit by torches, slopes downward, and has railway tracks. 
Harry learns about the contents of vault seven hundred and thirteen {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid refuses to tell Harry what is in the vault, claiming it is a secret Hogwarts business.
They arrive at vault number seven hundred and thirteen {tuple_delimiter} The vault contains mounds of gold coins, columns of silver, and heaps of bronze Knuts. 


{completion_delimiter}

Harry is introduced to the wizarding world and meets Draco Malfoy {tuple_delimiter} Harry receives a large sum of money from Gringotts and enters Madam Malkin's shop for his Hogwarts uniform. He encounters Draco Malfoy, who reveals he is also going to Hogwarts and comes from a wealthy wizarding family. 
Draco displays arrogance and prejudice towards Harry {tuple_delimiter} Draco boasts about his family's legacy in Slytherin House, criticizes Hufflepuff, and makes disparaging remarks about Hagrid, calling him a "savage." He also questions Harry about his parents' death with insensitivity.
Harry feels uncomfortable and increasingly dislikes Draco {tuple_delimiter}  Harry finds Draco's attitude and behavior unpleasant, particularly his snobbishness and lack of empathy. 


{completion_delimiter}

Harry is nervous about starting Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He is worried about being sorted into Hufflepuff and doesn't know much about Quidditch or other aspects of the wizarding world.
Hagrid reassures Harry about his concerns {tuple_delimiter} He explains that Slytherin has a bad reputation, but Harry shouldn't worry about being sorted there. Hagrid also provides information about Quidditch and the different Hogwarts houses. 
Harry is excited to learn magic {tuple_delimiter} He wants to find out how to curse Dudley and is fascinated by the magical objects in Flourish and Blotts.


{completion_delimiter}

Hagrid wants to get Harry an owl for his birthday {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid says that owls are dead useful, carry yer mail and everythin' and all the kids want them.
Harry gets a snowy owl from Eeylops Owl Emporium {tuple_delimiter}  They left the shop with Harry carrying a large cage holding a beautiful snowy owl. 
Ollivanders is a special place for wands {tuple_delimiter} The shop was narrow and shabby, dusty, and silent with thousands of narrow boxes piled up to the ceiling. It felt like a very strict library.
Mr. Ollivander knows about Harry's parents {tuple_delimiter} He said that Harry has his mother's eyes and mentioned her first wand which was made of willow. 
Mr. Ollivander also knows about Harry's father {tuple_delimiter} He said that Harry's father favored a mahogany wand, eleven inches long, pliable, with more power, excellent for transfiguration.
The wand chooses the wizard {tuple_delimiter} Mr. Ollivander stated that it is really the wand that chooses the wizard, not the other way around. 


{completion_delimiter}

Mr. Ollivander believes that Harry's wand was chosen for him {tuple_delimiter}  "The wand chooses the wizard, remember." and "I think we must expect great things from you, Mr. Potter."
Harry's wand is made of holly and phoenix feather {tuple_delimiter} "unusual combination — holly and phoenix feather, eleven inches, nice and supple.” 
The phoenix whose tail feather is in Harry's wand also gave another feather {tuple_delimiter} “I remember every wand I’ve ever sold, Mr. Potter. Every single wand. It so happens that the phoenix whose tail feather is in your wand, gave another feather — just one other. It is very curious indeed that you should be destined for this wand when its brother — why, its brother gave you that scar.”
Harry's scar was caused by the brother of his wand's phoenix feather {tuple_delimiter} “It so happens that the phoenix whose tail feather is in your wand, gave another feather — just one other. It is very curious indeed that you should be destined for this wand when its brother — why, its brother gave you that scar.”


{completion_delimiter}

Harry feels confused and inadequate about his fame as "The Boy Who Lived" {tuple_delimiter} He doesn't remember anything about the night his parents died or how he survived Voldemort's attack. Harry is unsure of his abilities and worries that he can't live up to expectations{tuple_delimiter} Hagrid reassures Harry, telling him that everyone starts at Hogwarts and that he will learn quickly. 
Harry's last month with the Dursleys is a mixed bag {tuple_delimiter} While they are less hostile towards him, treating him like an invisible presence, it becomes depressing for Harry. He finds solace in his new owl, Hedwig, and his school books about magic.  {tuple_delimiter} Harry tries to talk to his aunt and uncle about going to Hogwarts but they are dismissive and skeptical of the magical world. 
Uncle Vernon is reluctant to believe Harry's story about Platform Nine and Three-Quarters {tuple_delimiter} He calls it "rubbish" and "barking mad," but eventually agrees to take Harry to King's Cross because they are already going to London for Dudley's medical procedure.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry is nervous and excited about going to Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He checks his list, makes sure Hedwig is safe, and paces the room waiting for the Dursleys to wake up.
Harry's trunk is loaded into the car and they drive to King's Cross{tuple_delimiter} Uncle Vernon acts strangely kind by helping Harry with his trunk but then leads him to a non-existent platform nine and three-quarters. 
Harry is confused and stranded at the station{tuple_delimiter} He asks a guard for help but the guard doesn't know anything about Hogwarts, leaving Harry desperate and panicked.
Harry overhears a conversation about Platform Nine and Three-Quarters {tuple_delimiter} A family of redheads with their own trunks and owls are talking about going to Hogwarts. 
Harry watches as the oldest Weasley boy disappears through the barrier between platforms nine and ten{tuple_delimiter} He then sees the other two Weasley brothers disappear in the same way, leaving Harry to figure out how it works.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry Potter successfully arrives at Platform Nine and Three-Quarters {tuple_delimiter} He runs straight through the barrier between platforms nine and ten, as instructed by a kind woman, and finds himself on a platform with a scarlet steam engine labeled Hogwarts Express.
Harry boards the Hogwarts Express and meets the Weasley twins {tuple_delimiter}  He is helped by them to put his trunk in a compartment, and they recognize him as Harry Potter. 
The Weasley family bids farewell to Harry as he boards the train {tuple_delimiter} The youngest Weasley boy, Ron, gets cleaned up by his mother before Percy joins them.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry is fascinated by Ron's wizarding family {tuple_delimiter}  Ron tells Harry about his five older brothers who all excelled at Hogwarts, leaving him feeling pressured to live up to their achievements.
Ron feels pressure to succeed at Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He mentions his brothers' accomplishments: Bill was head boy, Charlie was Quidditch captain, Percy is a prefect, and Fred and George are funny and academically successful. 
Harry and Ron bond over their experiences {tuple_delimiter} They share stories about their families and how they learned about magic, finding common ground despite their different backgrounds.


{completion_delimiter}

Harry and Ron are enjoying their train ride to Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} They are eating Harry's sweets and sharing Chocolate Frogs which come with collectible cards of famous witches and wizards.
Ron is excited about collecting the cards, particularly missing Agrippa and Ptolemy {tuple_delimiter} He explains to Harry that Chocolate Frogs have cards inside them, you know, to collect — famous witches and wizards. I’ve got about five hundred, but I haven’t got Agrippa or Ptolemy.”
Harry learns about Albus Dumbledore, the Headmaster of Hogwarts, from Ron's card {tuple_delimiter} He is surprised to learn that Dumbledore's face disappears from the card and then reappears later. 


{completion_delimiter}

Ron is worried about being sorted into Slytherin {tuple_delimiter} He says, "I don't know what they'll say if I’m not in Gryffindor. I don’t suppose Ravenclaw would be too bad, but imagine if they put me in Slytherin." 
Hermione is a very knowledgeable witch {tuple_delimiter} She states that she has read all the course books by heart and knows about Harry from background reading.
Ron's brothers have interesting jobs after leaving Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} Charlie studies dragons in Romania, and Bill works for Gringotts bank in Africa. 


{completion_delimiter}

Draco Malfoy is a prejudiced and arrogant wizard who believes his family is superior to others {tuple_delimiter} He insults the Weasleys, stating they have red hair, freckles, and too many children, implying they are poor. He also warns Harry about associating with "riffraff" like Hagrid and the Weasleys, suggesting that such friendships will lead him down a bad path.
Harry Potter is brave and stands up to Draco Malfoy's bullying {tuple_delimiter} When Malfoy threatens Harry and his friends, Harry tells him to leave or face consequences. He also refuses to shake Malfoy's hand, showing his disdain for the arrogant wizard. 
Ron Weasley is loyal and protective of his friends {tuple_delimiter} He immediately stands up to Malfoy when he insults Harry and is ready to fight him. He also shows concern for Scabbers after the rat bites Goyle.


{completion_delimiter}

Ron's family has a complicated history with the Dark Side {tuple_delimiter} Ron says his father doesn't believe that the Malfoys were bewitched into joining You-Know-Who, implying they willingly chose to side with darkness.
The Hogwarts Express is nearing its destination {tuple_delimiter} Hermione informs Ron and Harry that the conductor announced their arrival at Hogwarts is imminent. 
Harry and Ron are nervous about arriving at Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter}  Both boys feel a sense of nervousness as the train slows down, evidenced by Harry's stomach lurching and Ron looking pale.
Hagrid greets the first-year students with enthusiasm {tuple_delimiter} Hagrid is depicted as welcoming and excited to lead the first years to Hogwarts, calling out to them and guiding them along the path. 


{completion_delimiter}

Professor McGonagall welcomes first years to Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} She explains that the Sorting Ceremony will place them into their Houses (Gryffindor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, and Slytherin), which will be like family during their time at Hogwarts.
The Sorting Ceremony is important because it determines where students will have classes, sleep, and spend free time {tuple_delimiter}  Professor McGonagall states that triumphs earn House points while rule-breaking loses them, with the House with the most points at the end of the year winning the House Cup. 
First years are nervous about the Sorting Ceremony {tuple_delimiter} Harry is particularly anxious as he doesn't know any magic yet and feels unprepared for a test in front of the whole school.  He observes that other students are also scared, except for Hermione Granger who seems confident and knowledgeable about spells.


{completion_delimiter}

The Sorting Ceremony is about to begin {tuple_delimiter} Professor McGonagall instructs the first years to line up and follow her into the Great Hall. The ceremony involves putting on a magical hat that sorts students into their respective houses.
The Great Hall is described as a magnificent space {tuple_delimiter} It is lit by floating candles, has long tables laden with golden plates and goblets, and a ceiling that appears to be the night sky. 
The Sorting Hat sings a song about its abilities {tuple_delimiter} The hat claims to be able to see everything hidden in a student's head and will sort them into one of four houses: Gryffindor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, or Slytherin.  
The first students are sorted into their houses {tuple_delimiter} Hannah Abbott is sorted into Hufflepuff, and Susan Bones also goes to Hufflepuff. Terry Boot is sorted into Ravenclaw. 

{completion_delimiter}

Harry is excited about being at Hogwarts {tuple_delimiter} He recognizes Dumbledore from a Chocolate Frog card and is impressed by his silver hair.  He also spots Professor Quirrell, who looks peculiar in a turban.
Ron is sorted into Gryffindor {tuple_delimiter} Harry crosses his fingers for Ron during the sorting ceremony and cheers when the hat shouts "GRYFFINDOR!" 
Dumbledore welcomes the students with a strange greeting {tuple_delimiter} Dumbledore greets the students with "Nitwit! Blubber! Oddment! Tweak!", which confuses Harry.  Percy assures Harry that Dumbledore is a genius but a bit mad.
The feast is extravagant and delicious {tuple_delimiter} The table is piled high with various foods, including roast beef, chicken, pork chops, sausages, bacon, steak, potatoes, gravy, ketchup, and peppermint humbugs. Harry enjoys the feast immensely.


{completion_delimiter}

The feast is described as lavish and plentiful {tuple_delimiter}  "Blocks of ice cream in every flavor you could think of, apple pies, treacle tarts, chocolate éclairs and jam doughnuts, trifle, strawberries, Jell-O, rice pudding . . ."

Neville describes his difficult upbringing by his Muggle family who didn't believe he was a witch {tuple_delimiter} "My Great Uncle Algie kept trying to catch me off my guard and force some magic out of me — he pushed me off the end of Blackpool pier once, I nearly drowned — but nothing happened until I was eight."

Harry experiences pain in his scar when a teacher named Snape looks at him {tuple_delimiter} "It happened very suddenly. The hook-nosed teacher looked past Quirrell’s turban straight into Harry’s eyes — and a sharp, hot pain shot across the scar on Harry’s forehead."

Professor Dumbledore warns students about several rules, including staying out of the Forbidden Forest, not using magic in the corridors, and avoiding the third-floor corridor {tuple_delimiter} "First years should note that the forest on the grounds is forbidden to all pupils.
